articles.title: Hono + Htmx + Cloudflare: A New Stack?
articles.description: A lot of people seem to be jumping on htmx lately as an alternative to the complexity of frameworks like React, but what if you want to keep using JSX? Hono is a (vaguely Express-like) Web framework targeting edge function use cases and includes middleware for rendering JSX. Yusuke gives a quick example of how all this can come together with Cloudflare Workers and D1 for a simpler, full-stack JS experience.
articles.author: Yusuke Wada

articles.title: Shrinking VS Code with Name Mangling
articles.description: There‚Äôs a fair bit of JavaScript in VS Code but the team has managed to reduce the size of the shipped code by almost 4MB without actually doing any deleting or refactoring thanks to a new ‚Äòname mangling‚Äô build step. This is a great read on how the team approached things and got it working.
articles.author: Matt Bierner

articles.title: Microsoft TypeChat: An Approach for Type-Safe LLM Responses
articles.description: A new project with some prominent names attached (the designer of C# and PM for TypeScript, for starters) that demonstrates the excitement within MS for large language models (LLMs). TypeChat aims to work around the problem of LLMs outputting hard-to-parse natural language and to direct such output into a predictable, typed form.
articles.author: Hejlsberg, Lucco, Rosenwasser et al.

articles.title: üíõ ¬†'Good Code is Like a Love Letter to The Next Developer Who Will Maintain¬†It'
articles.description: ‚ÄúThe beauty of our creations, however, is not judged solely by the elegance of our algorithms or the efficiency of our code, but by the joy and ease with which others can build upon our work.‚Äù
articles.author: Addy Osmani

articles.title: How to Build a GPT-3 App with Next.js, React, and GitHub Copilot
articles.description: GitHub doesn't often run tutorials on its blog, but they appear keen to promote the idea of a modern Copilot-oriented development process, and this certainly shows off some of the potential.
articles.author: Kedasha Kerr (GitHub)

articles.title: a11y-dialog 8.0: A Lightweight, Accessible Way to Create Dialogs
articles.description: Supports alert dialogs as per WAI-ARIA, nested dialogs, and provides both a DOM and JavaScript API. There‚Äôs a live CodeSandbox demo you can play with. v8.0 no longer supports IE, if that's important to you.
articles.author: Kitty Giraudel

articles.title: Mapkick.js: Interactive Maps in One Line of JavaScript
articles.description: Supports Mapbox and MapLibre. It also comes in Python and Ruby variants targeting server-side rendered use cases.
articles.author: Andrew Kane

articles.title: PLJS: JavaScript Language Plugin for Postgres
articles.description: PLV8 is the ‚Äògo to‚Äô extension to use JavaScript within Postgres, but this QuickJS-based variant, from the same creator, is more compact, easier to maintain, and may be enough for your needs.
articles.author: Jerry Sievert

articles.title: Twin 3.4: Use Tailwind Classes in CSS-in-JS Libraries
articles.description: Twin v3 introduced full Tailwind plugin support, and v3.4 adds a new SolidJS preset as well as styled-components 6 support.
articles.author: Ben Rogerson

articles.title: Praxis: An iOS Browser That Blocks JavaScript
articles.description: Well, that‚Äôs certainly one way to fight back against prompts, modals, and battery sapping scripts, but it won‚Äôt work with every site..
articles.author: Arnold Sakhnov

articles.title: Spectacle 10: A React and JSX-Based Presentation Library
articles.description: Got a presentation coming up? Build your decks with JSX, perhaps. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Formidable

articles.title: üò± ¬†Implementing Tic Tac Toe with 170MB of HTML
articles.description: Unsurprisingly, the demo (which we‚Äôve not linked to here) brought my browser to a crashing halt, but it‚Äôs fun to see a developer take on the challenge of using Chrome‚Äôs support for popovers and the state of said popovers along with a huge pile of HTML to handle a game of Tic Tac Toe. Don‚Äôt repeat this in production, folks..
articles.author: Gareth Heyes

articles.description: üê¶ React/Redux's Dan Abramov is leaving Meta. Having achieved so much and reaching a point where he feels ready to move on, Dan is departing Meta but will remain on the React team as an independent third party. üíô
üìò The Concise TypeScript Book is, unsurprisingly, a guide to using TypeScript. More surprisingly, it's all on GitHub and free to read. Hurrah.

Tixy is an interactive page for learning logic, math and expressions by solving puzzles using a visual grid. It starts off very simply, but gets elaborate quickly. This is a neat way to pick up some of the skills needed for Dwitter.
JSPlayground is a new Web-based JavaScript sandbox tool.
Is the term 'Jamstack' finished? Brian Rinaldi wonders.

Bun 0.7 ‚Äì The JavaScriptCore-based alternative JS runtime adds (experimental) Vite support, Web Workers support, and includes a --smol option to run in memory constrained environments (with a significant memory reduction shown off in the post).
Astro 2.9 ‚Äì The 'zero JS by default' framework adds experimental support for view transitions and more.
Neutralinojs v4.13.0 ‚Äì Lightweight cross-platform desktop app framework.
Remix 1.19 ‚Äì Modern full-stack JS framework.
Node.js v20.5.0 (Current)

articles.title: Core Web Vitals for Search Engine Optimization: What Do We Need to Know?
articles.description: Harry aims to clear up any misunderstandings around core web vitals metrics and how they might impact SEO. A well-sourced article.
articles.author: Harry Roberts

articles.title: Legibility: How and Why Typography Affects Ease of Reading
articles.description: A free seven chapter book from a typographic expert covering letter spacing, alignment, layout, rendering, aesthetics, and much more. An excellent resource on typographic variables that‚Äôs well worth a read for getting up to speed on all things legibility, readability and usability.
articles.author: Mary C. Dyson

articles.title: The Arc Browser Reaches v1.0
articles.description: I‚Äôve seen plenty of folks advocating for this new Chromium-powered browser ‚Äî and now, following a period of being invite only, it's finally publicly downloadable as a 1.0 release. (Release notes here)
articles.author: The Browser Company

articles.title: Google's 'Web Environment Integrity' Draft Draws Developer Ire
articles.description: This is a developing story worth keeping an eye on. Google has proposed an idea called Web Environment Integrity (WEI) as a way for clients to establish their ‚Äòintegrity‚Äô with a server by way of a third party. ‚ÄúIn simpler terms, WEI provides a way for a browser to prove it is working as a website operator expects, and hasn‚Äôt been manipulated.‚Äù Unsurprisingly, many folks see where this could lead..
articles.author: The Register

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†DX in the Frontend Developer Ecosystem
articles.description: A half-hour talk about frontend trends, new tools, and browser features, asking if we‚Äôre all busy reinventing the wheel for a reason or if sites built ‚Äòyesterday‚Äô may be as a good as those on the cutting edge.
articles.author: Stefan Judis

articles.title: Scroll Driven Animations in CSS are a Joy to Play Around With
articles.description: A look at some of the fun we can have with scroll driven animations ‚Äî giving us the chance to animate elements based on a scroll instead of time. This post looks at the basics, shares some ideas, and neat demos.
articles.author: Brecht De Ruyte

articles.title: Recreating YouTube‚Äôs Ambient Mode Glow Effect
articles.description: A look at how a little Canvas and requestAnimationFrame can come together to create that subtle glowing effect you see around YouTube videos.
articles.author: Adrian Bece

articles.title: WebGPU: The Cross-Platform Graphics API of Tomorrow?
articles.description: Learn how to build an app with WebGPU (using C++) for the web and specific platforms.
articles.author: Fran√ßois Beaufort

articles.title: How to Use CSS object-fit and object-position
articles.description: Learn how to use CSS object-fit to determine how images fit within a given space, and how to position those images with object-position.
articles.author: Ralph Mason

articles.title: Can We Query the Root Container?
articles.description: The complexities of containment, overflow, and ‚Äòpropagation‚Äô.
articles.author: Miriam Suzanne

articles.title: Easy SVG Sparklines
articles.description: With just a little SVG you can easily create sparkline charts that‚Äôll render in the browser and don‚Äôt require any JavaScript at all.
articles.author: Alex Plescan

articles.title: The Rise of JPEG XL: Apple's Support and Image Compression¬†Insights
articles.description: On the significance of Apple‚Äôs support for JPEG XL and what this means for the widespread adoption of this next-generation image compression format.
articles.author: JON SNEYERS

articles.title: TOAST UI Grid: A Customizable Grid Control for the Web
articles.description: A powerful MIT-licensed grid-style control for the display, editing, and management of data. It comes from the same folks as TUI Editor and TUI Calendar and while it‚Äôs happy on its own, there are wrappers for Vue and React too. GitHub repo.
articles.author: NHN

articles.title: wavesurfer.js 7: Audio Waveform Player
articles.description: If you‚Äôre creating a podcast player, audio experience, or anything where seeing an interactive audio waveform could be useful, check this out. GitHub repo.
articles.author: katspaugh and contributors

articles.title: Detect Scroll: A Fast, Light JS Module for Detecting Scroll Activity
articles.description: Expands on the browser‚Äôs limited scroll event listener to allow you to accurately detect direction and location on both axes.
articles.author: Jordan Egstad

articles.title: Winded: A Tool to Test Responsive Designs in Different Viewport Sizes Simultaneously
articles.description: Created for Tailwind sites (hence the name) but useful for testing any responsive design. Scanning multiple device sizes at a glance is a nice feature.
articles.author: Winded

articles.title: Tabler Icons: Over 4500 Vector Icons for the Web
articles.description: Open source icons you can use by either copying or downloading SVGs or PNGs or use one of the helper libraries like @tabler/icons-react to take them direct into a React app, say.
articles.author: Tabler

articles.title: React Tweet: A Fresh Way to Embed Tweets in a React App
articles.description: Vercel has come up with an elegant way to embed posts from the site formerly known as Twitter that's faster and smaller than the official mechanism and supports React Server Components and ‚Äòany React framework.‚Äô Now let's just hope Elon doesn‚Äôt turn off the taps..
articles.author: Vercel

articles.description: The folks at Devographics (the team behind the State of CSS) want your help in shaping the very first 'State of HTML' survey.
The third edition of the PNG spec has been published as a W3C Working Draft.
The No CSS Club is, unsurprisingly, a collection of sites that use no CSS at all. Don't expect anything pretty, but they're certainly fast.
Cloudflare's Radar Domain Rankings now track global trending domains.
